dt: {bc}to have as an {d_link|attribute|attribute:1}, knowledge, or skill
{bc}to seize and take control of {bc}take into one's {d_link|possession|possession}
{bc}to bring or cause to fall under the influence, domination, or control of some emotional or intellectual response or reaction
used in passive construction to indicate simple possession

quotes.t: What does matter is that we come to recognize that playfulness, as a philosophical stance, can be very serious, indeed; and, moreover, that it {qword}possesses{/qword} an unfailing capacity to arouse ridicule and hostility in those among us who crave certainty, reverence, and restraint.
What would {qword}possess{/qword} seemingly sane people to treat concrete walls like trampolines?

People who experience specific colors when looking at particular letters, such as seeing sky blue when shown an R, {qword}possess{/qword} an unusual abundance of connections in brain areas involved in word and color perception, a new brain-imaging investigation finds.

et: Middle English, from Middle French {it}possesser{/it} to have possession of, take possession of, from Latin {it}possessus{/it}, past participle of {it}possidēre{/it}, from {it}potis{/it} able, having the power + {it}sedēre{/it} to sit {ma}{mat|potent|}, {mat|sit|}{/ma}
shortdef: to have and hold as property : own
to have as an attribute, knowledge, or skill
to seize and take control of : take into one's possession
